lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Of my cousin Vernon's are not yet come up:
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Your uncle Worcester's horse came but today;
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: And now their pride and mettle is asleep,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Their courage with hard labour tame and dull,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: That not a horse is half the half of himself.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: So are the horses of the enemy
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: In general, journey-bated and brought low:
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: The better part of ours are full of rest.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The number of the king exceedeth ours:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: For God's sake. cousin, stay till all come in.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: I come with gracious offers from the king,
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: if you vouchsafe me hearing and respect.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt; and would to God
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: You were of our determination!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Some of us love you well; and even those some
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Envy your great deservings and good name,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Because you are not of our quality,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: But stand against us like an enemy.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: And God defend but still I should stand so,
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: So long as out of limit and true rule
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: You stand against anointed majesty.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: But to my charge. The king hath sent to know
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: The nature of your griefs, and whereupon
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: You conjure from the breast of civil peace
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Audacious cruelty. If that the king
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Have any way your good deserts forgot,
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Which he confesseth to be manifold,
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: He bids you name your griefs; and with all speed
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: You shall have your desires with interest
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: And pardon absolute for yourself and these
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Herein misled by your suggestion.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: The king is kind; and well we know the king
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Knows at what time to promise, when to pay.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: My father and my uncle and myself
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Did give him that same royalty he wears;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And when he was not six and twenty strong,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Sick in the world's regard, wretched and low,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: My father gave him welcome to the shore;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And when he heard him swear and vow to God
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: He came but to be Duke of Lancaster,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: To sue his livery and beg his peace,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: With tears of innocency and terms of zeal,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: My father, in kind heart and pity moved,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Swore him assistance and perform'd it too.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Now when the lords and barons of the realm
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Perceived Northumberland did lean to him,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: The more and less came in with cap and knee;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Met him in boroughs, cities, villages,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Attended him on bridges, stood in lanes,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Laid gifts before him, proffer'd him their oaths,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Gave him their heirs, as pages follow'd him
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Even at the heels in golden multitudes.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: He presently, as greatness knows itself,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Steps me a little higher than his vow
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Made to my father, while his blood was poor,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And now, forsooth, takes on him to reform
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Some certain edicts and some strait decrees
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: That lie too heavy on the commonwealth,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Cries out upon abuses, seems to weep
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Over his country's wrongs; and by this face,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: This seeming brow of justice, did he win
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: The hearts of all that he did angle for;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Proceeded further; cut me off the heads
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Of all the favourites that the absent king
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: In deputation left behind him here,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: When he was personal in the Irish war.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Tut, I came not to hear this.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Then to the point.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: In short time after, he deposed the king;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Soon after that, deprived him of his life;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And in the neck of that, task'd the whole state:
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: To make that worse, suffer'd his kinsman March,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Who is, if every owner were well placed,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Indeed his king, to be engaged in Wales,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: There without ransom to lie forfeited;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Disgraced me in my happy victories,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Sought to entrap me by intelligence;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Rated mine uncle from the council-board;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: In rage dismiss'd my father from the court;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Broke oath on oath, committed wrong on wrong,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And in conclusion drove us to seek out
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: This head of safety; and withal to pry
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Into his title, the which we find
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Too indirect for long continuance.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Shall I return this answer to the king?
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Not so, Sir Walter: we'll withdraw awhile.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Go to the king; and let there be impawn'd
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Some surety for a safe return again,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And in the morning early shall my uncle
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Bring him our purposes: and so farewell.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: I would you would accept of grace and love.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And may be so we shall.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: SIR WALTER BLUNT
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: Pray God you do.
lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Hie, good Sir Michael; bear this sealed brief
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: With winged haste to the lord marshal;
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: This to my cousin Scroop, and all the rest
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: To whom they are directed. If you knew
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: How much they do to import, you would make haste.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: SIR MICHAEL
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: My good lord,
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: I guess their tenor.
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Like enough you do.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: To-morrow, good Sir Michael, is a day
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Must bide the touch; for, sir, at Shrewsbury,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: As I am truly given to understand,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: The king with mighty and quick-raised power
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Meets with Lord Harry: and, I fear, Sir Michael,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: What with the sickness of Northumberland,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Whose power was in the first proportion,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And what with Owen Glendower's absence thence,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Who with them was a rated sinew too
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And comes not in, o'er-ruled by prophecies,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: I fear the power of Percy is too weak
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: To wage an instant trial with the king.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: SIR MICHAEL
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: Why, my good lord, you need not fear;
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: No, Mortimer is not there.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: SIR MICHAEL
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: And there is my Lord of Worcester and a head
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: Of gallant warriors, noble gentlemen.
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And so there is: but yet the king hath drawn
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: The special head of all the land together:
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: The noble Westmoreland and warlike Blunt;
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And moe corrivals and dear men
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Of estimation and command in arms.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: SIR MICHAEL
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: Doubt not, my lord, they shall be well opposed.
lines.speaker: SIR MICHAEL

lines.value: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: I hope no less, yet needful 'tis to fear;
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And, to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, speed:
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the king
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Dismiss his power, he means to visit us,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: For he hath heard of our confederacy,
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: And 'tis but wisdom to make strong against him:
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: Therefore make haste. I must go write again
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: To other friends; and so farewell, Sir Michael.
lines.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: How bloodily the sun begins to peer
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Above yon busky hill! the day looks pale
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: At his distemperature.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The southern wind
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Doth play the trumpet to his purposes,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And by his hollow whistling in the leaves
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Foretells a tempest and a blustering day.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Then with the losers let it sympathize,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: For nothing can seem foul to those that win.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: How now, my Lord of Worcester! 'tis not well
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: That you and I should meet upon such terms
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: As now we meet. You have deceived our trust,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And made us doff our easy robes of peace,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: To crush our old limbs in ungentle steel:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: This is not well, my lord, this is not well.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: What say you to it? will you again unknit
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: This curlish knot of all-abhorred war?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And move in that obedient orb again
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Where you did give a fair and natural light,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And be no more an exhaled meteor,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: A prodigy of fear and a portent
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Of broached mischief to the unborn times?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Hear me, my liege:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: For mine own part, I could be well content
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: To entertain the lag-end of my life
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: With quiet hours; for I do protest,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: I have not sought the day of this dislike.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: You have not sought it! how comes it, then?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Rebellion lay in his way, and he found it.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Peace, chewet, peace!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: It pleased your majesty to turn your looks
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Of favour from myself and all our house;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And yet I must remember you, my lord,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: We were the first and dearest of your friends.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: For you my staff of office did I break
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: In Richard's time; and posted day and night
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: to meet you on the way, and kiss your hand,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: When yet you were in place and in account
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Nothing so strong and fortunate as I.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: It was myself, my brother and his son,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: That brought you home and boldly did outdare
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The dangers of the time. You swore to us,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And you did swear that oath at Doncaster,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: That you did nothing purpose 'gainst the state;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Nor claim no further than your new-fall'n right,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The seat of Gaunt, dukedom of Lancaster:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: To this we swore our aid. But in short space
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: It rain'd down fortune showering on your head;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And such a flood of greatness fell on you,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: What with our help, what with the absent king,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: What with the injuries of a wanton time,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The seeming sufferances that you had borne,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And the contrarious winds that held the king
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: So long in his unlucky Irish wars
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: That all in England did repute him dead:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And from this swarm of fair advantages
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: You took occasion to be quickly woo'd
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: To gripe the general sway into your hand;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Forget your oath to us at Doncaster;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And being fed by us you used us so
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: As that ungentle hull, the cuckoo's bird,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Useth the sparrow; did oppress our nest;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Grew by our feeding to so great a bulk
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: That even our love durst not come near your sight
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: For fear of swallowing; but with nimble wing
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: We were enforced, for safety sake, to fly
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Out of sight and raise this present head;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Whereby we stand opposed by such means
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: As you yourself have forged against yourself
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: By unkind usage, dangerous countenance,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And violation of all faith and troth
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Sworn to us in your younger enterprise.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: These things indeed you have articulate,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Proclaim'd at market-crosses, read in churches,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: To face the garment of rebellion
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: With some fine colour that may please the eye
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Of fickle changelings and poor discontents,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Which gape and rub the elbow at the news
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Of hurlyburly innovation:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And never yet did insurrection want
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Such water-colours to impaint his cause;
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Nor moody beggars, starving for a time
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Of pellmell havoc and confusion.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: In both your armies there is many a soul
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Shall pay full dearly for this encounter,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: If once they join in trial. Tell your nephew,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The Prince of Wales doth join with all the world
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: In praise of Henry Percy: by my hopes,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: This present enterprise set off his head,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I do not think a braver gentleman,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: More active-valiant or more valiant-young,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: More daring or more bold, is now alive
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: To grace this latter age with noble deeds.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: For my part, I may speak it to my shame,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I have a truant been to chivalry;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And so I hear he doth account me too;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Yet this before my father's majesty--
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I am content that he shall take the odds
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Of his great name and estimation,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And will, to save the blood on either side,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Try fortune with him in a single fight.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And, Prince of Wales, so dare we venture thee,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Albeit considerations infinite
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Do make against it. No, good Worcester, no,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: We love our people well; even those we love
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: That are misled upon your cousin's part;
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And, will they take the offer of our grace,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Both he and they and you, every man
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Shall be my friend again and I'll be his:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: So tell your cousin, and bring me word
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: What he will do: but if he will not yield,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Rebuke and dread correction wait on us
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And they shall do their office. So, be gone;
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: We will not now be troubled with reply:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: We offer fair; take it advisedly.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: It will not be accepted, on my life:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The Douglas and the Hotspur both together
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Are confident against the world in arms.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Hence, therefore, every leader to his charge;
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: For, on their answer, will we set on them:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And God befriend us, as our cause is just!
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Hal, if thou see me down in the battle and bestride
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: me, so; 'tis a point of friendship.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Nothing but a colossus can do thee that friendship.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Say thy prayers, and farewell.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: I  would 'twere bed-time, Hal, and all well.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Why, thou owest God a death.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: 'Tis not due yet; I would be loath to pay him before
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: his day. What need I be so forward with him that
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: calls not on me? Well, 'tis no matter; honour pricks
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: me on. Yea, but how if honour prick me off when I
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: come on? how then? Can honour set to a leg? no: or
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: an arm? no: or take away the grief of a wound? no.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Honour hath no skill in surgery, then? no. What is
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: honour? a word. What is in that word honour? what
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: is that honour? air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it?
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: he that died o' Wednesday. Doth he feel it? no.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Doth he hear it? no. 'Tis insensible, then. Yea,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: to the dead. But will it not live with the living?
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: no. Why? detraction will not suffer it. Therefore
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: I'll none of it. Honour is a mere scutcheon: and so
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: ends my catechism.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: O, no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The liberal and kind offer of the king.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: VERNON
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: 'Twere best he did.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Then are we all undone.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: It is not possible, it cannot be,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The king should keep his word in loving us;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: He will suspect us still and find a time
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: To punish this offence in other faults:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Suspicion all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: For treason is but trusted like the fox,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Who, ne'er so tame, so cherish'd and lock'd up,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Will have a wild trick of his ancestors.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Look how we can, or sad or merrily,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Interpretation will misquote our looks,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And we shall feed like oxen at a stall,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The better cherish'd, still the nearer death.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: My nephew's trespass may be well forgot;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: it hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And an adopted name of privilege,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: A hair-brain'd Hotspur, govern'd by a spleen:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: All his offences live upon my head
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And on his father's; we did train him on,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And, his corruption being ta'en from us,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: We, as the spring of all, shall pay for all.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Therefore, good cousin, let not Harry know,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: In any case, the offer of the king.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: VERNON
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Deliver what you will; I'll say 'tis so.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Here comes your cousin.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: My uncle is return'd:
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Uncle, what news?
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The king will bid you battle presently.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: Defy him by the Lord of Westmoreland.
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Lord Douglas, go you and tell him so.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: Marry, and shall, and very willingly.
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: There is no seeming mercy in the king.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Did you beg any? God forbid!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: I told him gently of our grievances,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Of his oath-breaking; which he mended thus,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: By now forswearing that he is forsworn:
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: He calls us rebels, traitors; and will scourge
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: With haughty arms this hateful name in us.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: Arm, gentlemen; to arms! for I have thrown
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: A brave defiance in King Henry's teeth,
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: And Westmoreland, that was engaged, did bear it;
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: Which cannot choose but bring him quickly on.
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: The Prince of Wales stepp'd forth before the king,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And, nephew, challenged you to single fight.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: O, would the quarrel lay upon our heads,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And that no man might draw short breath today
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: But I and Harry Monmouth! Tell me, tell me,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: How show'd his tasking? seem'd it in contempt?
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: VERNON
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: No, by my soul; I never in my life
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Did hear a challenge urged more modestly,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Unless a brother should a brother dare
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: To gentle exercise and proof of arms.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: He gave you all the duties of a man;
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Trimm'd up your praises with a princely tongue,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Spoke to your deservings like a chronicle,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Making you ever better than his praise
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: By still dispraising praise valued in you;
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: And, which became him like a prince indeed,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: He made a blushing cital of himself;
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: And chid his truant youth with such a grace
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: As if he master'd there a double spirit.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: Of teaching and of learning instantly.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: There did he pause: but let me tell the world,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: If he outlive the envy of this day,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: England did never owe so sweet a hope,
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: So much misconstrued in his wantonness.
lines.speaker: VERNON

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Cousin, I think thou art enamoured
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: On his follies: never did I hear
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Of any prince so wild a libertine.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: But be he as he will, yet once ere night
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: I will embrace him with a soldier's arm,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: That he shall shrink under my courtesy.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Arm, arm with speed: and, fellows, soldiers, friends,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Better consider what you have to do
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Than I, that have not well the gift of tongue,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Can lift your blood up with persuasion.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Messenger
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: My lord, here are letters for you.
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: I cannot read them now.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: O gentlemen, the time of life is short!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: To spend that shortness basely were too long,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: If life did ride upon a dial's point,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Still ending at the arrival of an hour.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: An if we live, we live to tread on kings;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: If die, brave death, when princes die with us!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Now, for our consciences, the arms are fair,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: When the intent of bearing them is just.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Messenger
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: My lord, prepare; the king comes on apace.
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: I thank him, that he cuts me from my tale,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: For I profess not talking; only this--
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Let each man do his best: and here draw I
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: A sword, whose temper I intend to stain
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: With the best blood that I can meet withal
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: In the adventure of this perilous day.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Now, Esperance! Percy! and set on.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Sound all the lofty instruments of war,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And by that music let us all embrace;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: For, heaven to earth, some of us never shall
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: A second time do such a courtesy.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Our soldiers stand full fairly for the day.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Though I could 'scape shot-free at London, I fear
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: the shot here; here's no scoring but upon the pate.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Soft! who are you? Sir Walter Blunt: there's honour
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: for you! here's no vanity! I am as hot as moulten
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: lead, and as heavy too: God keep lead out of me! I
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: need no more weight than mine own bowels. I have
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: led my ragamuffins where they are peppered: there's

lines.value: not three of my hundred and fifty left alive; and

lines.value: they are for the town's end, to beg during life.

lines.value: But who comes here?

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Whose deaths are yet unrevenged: I prithee,

lines.value: lend me thy sword.

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: O Hal, I prithee, give me leave to breathe awhile.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: He is, indeed; and living to kill thee. I prithee,

lines.value: lend me thy sword.

lines.value: Nay, before God, Hal, if Percy be alive, thou get'st

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Give it to me: what, is it in the case?

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Ay, Hal; 'tis hot, 'tis hot; there's that will sack a city.

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: willingly, let him make a carbonado of me. I like
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: not such grinning honour as Sir Walter hath: give me
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: life: which if I can save, so; if not, honour comes
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: unlooked for, and there's an end.

lines.value: I prithee,

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Lead me, my lord? I do not need your help:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And God forbid a shallow scratch should drive
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Where stain'd nobility lies trodden on,

lines.value: and rebels' arms triumph in massacres!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: We breathe too long: come, cousin Westmoreland,

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: By God, thou hast deceived me, Lancaster;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: With lustier maintenance than I did look for
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Of such an ungrown warrior.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: O, this boy

lines.value: Lends mettle to us all!

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: Another king! they grow like Hydra's heads:
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: I am the Douglas, fatal to all those
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: That wear those colours on them: what art thou,

lines.value: That counterfeit'st the person of a king?
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: The king himself; who, Douglas, grieves at heart
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: So many of his shadows thou hast met
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And not the very king. I have two boys

lines.value: Seek Percy and thyself about the field:

lines.value: But, seeing thou fall'st on me so luckily,

lines.value: EARL OF DOUGLAS
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: I fear thou art another counterfeit;
lines.speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Hold up thy head, vile Scot, or thou art like
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Never to hold it up again! the spirits
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Of valiant Shirley, Stafford, Blunt, are in my arms:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: It is the Prince of Wales that threatens thee;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Who never promiseth but he means to pay.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Cheerly, my lord	how fares your grace?
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Sir Nicholas Gawsey hath for succor sent,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And so hath Clifton: I'll to Clifton straight.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Stay, and breathe awhile:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Thou hast redeem'd thy lost opinion,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And show'd thou makest some tender of my life,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: In this fair rescue thou hast brought to me.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: O God! they did me too much injury
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: That ever said I hearken'd for your death.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: If it were so, I might have let alone
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The insulting hand of Douglas over you,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Which would have been as speedy in your end
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: As all the poisonous potions in the world
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And saved the treacherous labour of your son.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Make up to Clifton: I'll to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: If I mistake not, thou art Harry Monmouth.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Thou speak'st as if I would deny my name.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: My name is Harry Percy.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Why, then I see
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: A very valiant rebel of the name.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I am the Prince of Wales; and think not, Percy,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: To share with me in glory any more:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Two stars keep not their motion in one sphere;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Nor can one England brook a double reign,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Of Harry Percy and the Prince of Wales.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Nor shall it, Harry; for the hour is come
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: To end the one of us; and would to God
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Thy name in arms were now as great as mine!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I'll make it greater ere I part from thee;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And all the budding honours on thy crest
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I'll crop, to make a garland for my head.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: I can no longer brook thy vanities.
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Well said, Hal! to it Hal! Nay, you shall find no
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: boy's play here, I can tell you.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: HOTSPUR
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: O, Harry, thou hast robb'd me of my youth!
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: I better brook the loss of brittle life
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Than those proud titles thou hast won of me;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: They wound my thoughts worse than sword my flesh:
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: But thought's the slave of life, and life time's fool;
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And time, that takes survey of all the world,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Must have a stop. O, I could prophesy,
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: But that the earthy and cold hand of death
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: Lies on my tongue: no, Percy, thou art dust
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: And food for--
lines.speaker: HOTSPUR

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: For worms, brave Percy: fare thee well, great heart!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Ill-weaved ambition, how much art thou shrunk!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: When that this body did contain a spirit,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: A kingdom for it was too small a bound;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: But now two paces of the vilest earth
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Is room enough: this earth that bears thee dead
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Bears not alive so stout a gentleman.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: If thou wert sensible of courtesy,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I should not make so dear a show of zeal:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: But let my favours hide thy mangled face;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And, even in thy behalf, I'll thank myself
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: For doing these fair rites of tenderness.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Adieu, and take thy praise with thee to heaven!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Thy ignominy sleep with thee in the grave,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: But not remember'd in thy epitaph!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: What, old acquaintance! could not all this flesh
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Keep in a little life? Poor Jack, farewell!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I could have better spared a better man:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: O, I should have a heavy miss of thee,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: If I were much in love with vanity!
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Death hath not struck so fat a deer to-day,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Though many dearer, in this bloody fray.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Embowell'd will I see thee by and by:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Till then in blood by noble Percy lie.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: [Rising up]  Embowelled! if thou embowel me to-day,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: I'll give you leave to powder me and eat me too
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: to-morrow. 'Sblood,'twas time to counterfeit, or
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: that hot termagant Scot had paid me scot and lot too.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Counterfeit? I lie, I am no counterfeit: to die,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: is to be a counterfeit; for he is but the
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: counterfeit of a man who hath not the life of a man:
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: but to counterfeit dying, when a man thereby
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: liveth, is to be no counterfeit, but the true and
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: perfect image of life indeed. The better part of
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: valour is discretion; in the which better part I
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: have saved my life.'Zounds, I am afraid of this
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: gunpowder Percy, though he be dead: how, if he
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: should counterfeit too and rise? by my faith, I am
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: afraid he would prove the better counterfeit.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Therefore I'll make him sure; yea, and I'll swear I
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: killed him. Why may not he rise as well as I?
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Nothing confutes me but eyes, and nobody sees me.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Therefore, sirrah,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: with a new wound in your thigh, come you along with me.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Come, brother John; full bravely hast thou flesh'd
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Thy maiden sword.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: LANCASTER
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: But, soft! whom have we here?
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: Did you not tell me this fat man was dead?
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I did; I saw him dead,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Breathless and bleeding on the ground. Art
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: thou alive?
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Or is it fantasy that plays upon our eyesight?
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I prithee, speak; we will not trust our eyes
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Without our ears: thou art not what thou seem'st.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: No, that's certain; I am not a double man: but if I
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: be not Jack Falstaff, then am I a Jack. There is Percy:
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: if your father will do me any honour, so; if not, let
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: him kill the next Percy himself. I look to be either
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: earl or duke, I can assure you.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Why, Percy I killed myself and saw thee dead.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: Didst thou? Lord, Lord, how this world is given to
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: lying! I grant you I was down and out of breath;
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: and so was he: but we rose both at an instant and
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: fought a long hour by Shrewsbury clock. If I may be
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: believed, so; if not, let them that should reward
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: valour bear the sin upon their own heads. I'll take
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: it upon my death, I gave him this wound in the
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: thigh: if the man were alive and would deny it,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: 'zounds, I would make him eat a piece of my sword.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: LANCASTER
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: This is the strangest tale that ever I heard.
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: This is the strangest fellow, brother John.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Come, bring your luggage nobly on your back:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: For my part, if a lie may do thee grace,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I'll gild it with the happiest terms I have.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The trumpet sounds retreat; the day is ours.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Come, brother, let us to the highest of the field,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: To see what friends are living, who are dead.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: FALSTAFF
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: I'll follow, as they say, for reward. He that
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: rewards me, God reward him! If I do grow great,
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: I'll grow less; for I'll purge, and leave sack, and
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: live cleanly as a nobleman should do.
lines.speaker: FALSTAFF

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Thus ever did rebellion find rebuke.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Ill-spirited Worcester! did not we send grace,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Pardon and terms of love to all of you?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And wouldst thou turn our offers contrary?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Misuse the tenor of thy kinsman's trust?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Three knights upon our party slain to-day,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: A noble earl and many a creature else
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Had been alive this hour,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: If like a Christian thou hadst truly borne
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Betwixt our armies true intelligence.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: EARL OF WORCESTER
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: What I have done my safety urged me to;
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: And I embrace this fortune patiently,
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: Since not to be avoided it falls on me.
lines.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Bear Worcester to the death and Vernon too:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Other offenders we will pause upon.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: How goes the field?
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The noble Scot, Lord Douglas, when he saw
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The fortune of the day quite turn'd from him,
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The noble Percy slain, and all his men
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Upon the foot of fear, fled with the rest;
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: And falling from a hill, he was so bruised
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: That the pursuers took him. At my tent
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: The Douglas is; and I beseech your grace
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: I may dispose of him.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: With all my heart.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: PRINCE HENRY
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Then, brother John of Lancaster, to you
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: This honourable bounty shall belong:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Go to the Douglas, and deliver him
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free:
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: His valour shown upon our crests to-day
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Hath taught us how to cherish such high deeds
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: Even in the bosom of our adversaries.
lines.speaker: PRINCE HENRY

lines.value: LANCASTER
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: I thank your grace for this high courtesy,
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: Which I shall give away immediately.
lines.speaker: LANCASTER

lines.value: KING HENRY IV
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Then this remains, that we divide our power.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: You, son John, and my cousin Westmoreland
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Towards York shall bend you with your dearest speed,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: To meet Northumberland and the prelate Scroop,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Who, as we hear, are busily in arms:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Myself and you, son Harry, will towards Wales,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: To fight with Glendower and the Earl of March.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Rebellion in this land shall lose his sway,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Meeting the cheque of such another day:
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: And since this business so fair is done,
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV

lines.value: Let us not leave till all our own be won.
lines.speaker: KING HENRY IV
